Description: This virtual tour tells the history of the Yolo Basin Foundation and the geography of the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area.
Description 2: Scroll through the multimedia narrative and explore the accomanying map layers, or use the buttons above to jump to a particular chapter. You can also zoom in and out on the map using the +/- controls, and click to zoom/pan.

Description: The Central Valley, California's agricultural heartland, is an 18,000-square-mile sedimentary valley, fed by vast watershed of the Sacramento and San Joaquin Rivers.
Description 2: The valley's drainage area extends to the crests of the Sierra Nevada and the coast range, a catchment for rain and snowmelt that encompasses 60,000 square miles. Water from the Sacramento and San Joaquin Rivers and their tributaries converge at the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta--a highly modified landscape of tidal sloughs and canals surrounding levee-protected agricultural lowlands--before flowing out to sea via the San Francisco Bay.

Description: The Central Valley was once a complex mosaic of grasslands and riparian valley oak forests, transitioning to freshwater wetlands and tidal channels at the Delta.
Description 2: Zoom in to see a detailed map of the Delta from a historical ecology study by the San Francisco Estuary Institute (SFEI), which indicates a combination of freshwater emergent wetland and seasonal wet meadows at the location of today's Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area. Distributary channels once branched out from Putah Creek to spread water into the wetlands and meadows.

Description: Euro-American settlement began with the Mexican land grant ranchos, and expanded as the Delta's fertile soil attracted farmers and ranchers during the Gold Rush period.
Description 2: The natural levees on the banks of the Sacramento River supported settlements and farms, including the growing city of Sacramento (formerly known as New Helvetia).
Map Credit: Map of the Valley of the Sacramento including the Gold Region (1848) retrieved from David Rumsey Map Collection.

Description: The historic Yolo Basin describes a vast, low-lying wetland filled by distributary streams from the west and Sacramento River overflow to the east.
One of the major western tributaries is Putah Creek, whose water historically entered the basin, spread out and infiltrated into the soil at the Putah Creek Sinks.
Beginning with the Swamp Land Act of 1850, earthen flood control levees were constructed to support Delta farming by 'reclaiming' seasonal wetlands like the Yolo Basin.
Description 2: Settlements in the Sacramento Valley continued to grow, vulnerable to rising river levels from winter storms and spring snowmelt that culminated in the destructive flood of 1862.

Description: In 1917, the US Congress authorized the Sacramento River Flood Control Project, a system of levees and weirs that direct flood waters away from developed areas and into the designated undeveloped Sutter and Yolo bypasses.
Media Credit: Animated overview of the Sacramento River Flood Control System produced by the US Army Corps of Engineers

Description: The 92-square-mile Yolo Bypass begins at Fremont Weir, along the Sacramento River just northwest of the City of Sacramento, and extends south to the Delta.
Description 2: In wet winters, water from the Sacramento River rises high enough to spill over the Fremont Weir and flood the Yolo Bypass. The California Department of Water Resources can open and close the Sacramento Weir to let in additional water from the Sacramento River (and, during floods, the American River). The bypass also receives perennial inflow from Cache Creek and Putah Creek, along with Willow Slough and the Knights Landing ridge cut, to its west.

Description: Fully inundated, the Yolo Bypass becomes a vast "inland sea," conveying flood waters from several sources across the Sacramento Valley.
Description 2: The different sources of water are visible in this aerial photograph, owing to the varying sediment loads in the Sacramento River versus the tributary streams.

Description: To facilitate crossing the Yolo Bypass and expand commerce between Sacramento and the San Francisco Bay Area, the Yolo Causeway was built around the same time as the flood control project, in 1917.
Description 2: Before the causeway was built, there was no year-round route across the wetlands. Winter travelers had to venture across the flooded tule marshes by ferryboat, a dangerous crossing during high waters.

Description: One of the early settlers of the Yolo Basin was J.H. Glide, who purchased a large area in the 1870s that would eventually become much of the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area.
Description 2: The Glide family constructed levees to reclaim wetland into dry grazing land, and built a large and successful cattle and sheep business.
Map Credit: Official Map of Yolo County, California. Compiled from Official Records by C.C. Stitt, County Surveyor, 1939 retrieved from David Rumsey Historical Map Collection.

Description: The Yolo Bypass is an important stop along the Pacific Flyway, a north-south migratory pathway along which hundreds of millions of birds travel each year. Sacramento Valley wetlands provide critical overwintering habitat for waterfowl that then return to the Canadian Arctic for the summer.
Description 2: The lines on this map are GPS tracks of migratory ducks and geese collected by the USGS Dixon Field Station.
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: Over time, more and more wetland habitat in the Yolo Basin, the Delta and the greater Sacramento Valley was drained and converted to agricultural and urban land….
…until by the 1990s, almost no remnant wetland habitat remained in the Yolo Basin.

Chapter: Founding the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area
Description: The origin story of the Yolo Basin Foundation and the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area is a story of partnerships. Creating and protecting these thousands of acres of wetland habitat required cooperation between state agencies and private landowners, hunters and birdwatchers, farmers, and conservationists.
The story begins as a community effort, born at a kitchen table in Davis.
Description 2: Building off the success of the Putah Creek Council in negotiating new minimum flows for Putah Creek, the Yolo Basin Working Group was formed to restore and protect wetlands in the Yolo Basin, the creek's downstream destination.

Description: Recognizing that most of the potential land for a wetland restoration was privately owned, the Working Group decided to work with—instead of in opposition to—local landowners.
Description 2: In February 1990, the Yolo Basin Working Group sponsored a meeting with area landowners at the California Trucking Association Building in West Sacramento to discuss the proposal for a Yolo Basin Wildlife Area.

Description: The same month, the Yolo Basin Foundation was officially founded to advocate for and coordinate the building of a new Wildlife Area.
They sought the support of elected officials who would become critical advocates of the project's success, including Congressman Vic Fazio and Yolo County Supervisor Betsy Marchand.
The first Bucks for Ducks fundraiser was held in 1991, benefitting the wetlands project and supporting local arts.

Thanks to the wide-ranging collaboration and advocacy efforts, in December 1991, the State Wildlife Conservation Board completed the purchase of the 3100-acre Putah Creek Sinks property, for $4.57 in Proposition 70 funds.

On 13 February 1992, Congressman Fazio and US Army Corps of Engineers project members held a dedication event to celebrate the purchase. Two months later, the USACE released the final environmental assessment report.
The wetland restoration design took shape over the next two years. Initial concept plans envisioned a mosaic of temporary and permanent wetlands across the Putah Creek Sinks site.
The project also included a stormwater and wastewater treatment wetland for the City of Davis.
The first California Duck Days wetlands and wildlife festival, held February 1994, was the first of many family and educational activities centered around the Yolo Basin.
Meanwhile, volunteers with the Yolo Basin Foundation were already hard at work planting willows and cottonwoods for the riparian forest restoration.
The 25 April 1994 Signing Ceremony marked major progress on the Yolo Basin Wetlands Project.
Description 2: Endangered Species MOU and Management Agreement are signed by Dave Kennedy, Director of Dept. of Water Resources, Boyd Gibbons, Director of Dept. of Fish and Game, Ray Barsch, General Manager, State Reclamation Board, Wayne White, State Supervisor, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, and Doug Wheeler, Secretary, State Resources Agency.

Description: By 1995, the designs and plans for the wetland restoration had taken shape, and construction was ready to begin!
Over 150 people attended the groundbreaking ceremony in front of the restored riparian forest on 17 August 1995.
Description 2: Speakers included master of ceremonies, Supervisor Betsy Marchand, Secretary of the Interior Bruce Babbitt, Congressman Vic Fazio, Brig. General Bruce Scott, USACOE, Colonel John Reese, USACOE, Michael Spear, Regional Director USFWS, Robin Kulakow, Yolo Basin Foundation, Douglas Wheeler, Secretary of California Resources Agency, Jim Sarro, Wildlife Conservation Board, and Dr. Alan Wentz, Ducks Unlimited. Yolo Basin Foundation received the Dept. of the Interior National Wetlands Conservation Award for the private sector, from Western Region, USFWS.

Description: By November 1995, after months of grading and earthwork, the first phase of construction had completed, with 800 acres of new wetland ponds.
Description 2: The next month, during the Christmas bird count, the first flock of pintails was observed alighting over the new ponds. Construction on the remaining wetlands continued over the next two years.

Description: With construction finishing up, the Yolo Basin Foundation moved into its own office at the new Fish and Game headquarters, a couple miles down Chiles Road from the Wildlife Area.
On 15 November 1997, the Wildlife Area reached the national spotlight with a dedication ceremony and opening celebration attended by President Clinton and 800 other supporters.
Description 2: In addition to the President, speakers at the ceremony at Parking Lot C included Congressman Vic Fazio, John Garamendi, Assistant Deputy Director of US Dept. of the Interior, John Zhirsky, Assistant Secretary of Civil Works for US Army Corps of Engineers, Doug Wheeler, Secretary of State Resources Agency, Richard Rominger, Assistant Secretary of US Dept. of Agriculture. The ceremony marked the transfer of the wildlife area from the US Army Corps of Engineers, who oversaw the design and construction of the project, to California Fish and Game, who would manage it going forward.

Description: Yolo Basin Foundation's Robin Kulakow, Congressman Vic Fazio, and ___ led President Clinton on a rainy walk along a levee through one of the seasonal wetland ponds.
The Demonstration Wetlands at the headquarters were flooded up for the first time in August 1998, after 400 new trees were installed and irrigated.
Description 2: The Demonstration Wetlands would soon become the core of the Foundation's educational programs.

Description: Three years later, December 2001 saw the purchase of 12,000 additional acres of land for the Wildlife Area.
Description 2: The Glide Causeway Ranch, Giverson Ranch and Tule Ranch properties, along with the Los Rios Farms properties along Putah Creek, expanded the Wildlife Area to a total of 16,000 acres. This same year, the new Yolo Bypass Management Strategy was published after two years of meeting between land owners, water users, and public agencies.

Description: Over the ensuing years, the Yolo Basin Foundation continued to grow its community footprint through the Discover the Flyway educational program...
...and continued to build partnerships with public agencies, land owners, and water users for management.
Description 2: For example, the Yolo Basin Foundation with the mosquito district to become an early adopter of now-standard mosquito abatement best practices for wetland restoration projects, including water level management and seasonal mowing and disking of emergent vegetation.

Description: By the time the Wildlife Area celebrated its 10th anniversary with a celebration at Parking Lot B, ________...
...and the 25th anniversary...

As ecosystems change, water supply fluctuates, and new scientific knowledge develops, the Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area must be actively managed to balance the parallel goals of flood protection, agriculture, and wildlife conservation. Adapting to changing conditions requires continued partnership between agencies and land owners.
Description 2: In this section, we will learn about the mosaic of different land uses in the Wildlife Area, and the way they change seasonally throughout the year. This map outlines the fields and ponds that make up the Wildlife Area, colored by their uses. The Wildlife Area spans 16,000 acres including over 7,000 acres of wetlands.

Description: Permanent ponds, 4 to 5 feet deep, are filled with water year-round.
Description 2: These ponds provide year-round habitat for the area's resident waterfowl, including those that nest in the wildlife area during the summer: coots, mallards, gadwalls, and cinnamon teal. Green's Lake in the northeast is a remnant oxbow lake that dates back to the pre-development Sacramento River Valley.

Description: Seasonal wetlands are shallower, 6-18 inches deep. These ponds, planted with tule and cattail, are filled with water in the fall through spring.
Description 2: Wetlands are flooded in September/October to provide wintering habitat for large numbers of migratory waterfowl.

Description: Seasonal wetlands are drained in April before invasive weeds can establish. They are restored, seeded and irrigated over the summer prior to the next fall inundation.
Description 2: Some wetlands are first partially-drained ot provide shallow spring shorebird habitat.

Description: Putah Creek flows into the wildlife area from the west, carrying water from Lake Berryessa.
Description 2: The creek eventually flows into the toe drain that runs alongside the levee of the Sacramento Deep Water Ship Canal, and out to the Delta.

Description: Stretches of riparian woodland and scrub line water bodies including Putah Creek and Green's Lake.
Description 2: Trees such as cottonwood, willow, oregon ash, box elder, and blue elderberry support land mammals and nesting birds of prey.

Description: Alongside dedicated wetlands, the Wildlife Area also supports 2,400 acres of rice cultivation.
Description 2: Rice is planted in May-June and harvested in September. This collaboration between local rice growers and the state helps with land management costs and creates bird friendly habitat.

Description: After the harvest, starting in November, the rice fields are flooded to provide additional expanses of wetland habitat for migratory waterfowl and shorebirds.
Description 2: Fields are eventually drained the next March as migratory waterfowl and shorebirds begin to head north, to prepare for the next season's harvest.
Media Credit: add video of birds in flooded rice fields

Description: Rice farmers are required to set aside two parcels of land for summertime shorebird habitat.
Description 2: These areas are flooded in succession in July and August to provide the shallow water foraging habitat preferred by migrating shorebirds returning to the wildlife area in late summer..

Description: About 5,000 acres of irrigated and dryland pasture provide upland habitat alongside grazing range.
Description 2: The bypass also includes upland agriculture uses including tomatoes, sunflower, safflower, corn, and milo.

Description: The southern grasslands of the wildlife area include rare vernal pool and playa pool formations--ephemeral wetlands formed in shallow depressions that fill throughout the rainy season.
Description 2: As they dry in the spring, characteristic rings of wildflowers form along the receding shoreline in response to changing soil moisture. Flowers include goldfields, miniature lupine, butter-and-eggs, dowingia, monkey flower, and tidy tips.
Media Credit: Vernal pools and the umbrella barn at Glide Tule Ranch © Skyler Lewis

Description: The Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area is located off Interstate 80 between Davis and Sacramento.
Description 2: Take exit 78 from I-80 to visit the wildlife area (just east of the exit) and the headquarters (2 miles west on Chiles Rd).

Description: Take advantage of the popular auto tour loop for year-round wildlife viewing that passes through permanent ponds, seasonal wetlands, and rice fields.
Several hiking trails are accessible year round.
Description 2: Get out of the car at Parking Lot C and take the loop along the Tule Trail to see seasonal wetlands to the west and permanent ponds to the east.

Description: In the late fall and winter, the Wildlife Area is a hunting destination.
Description 2: Duck hunting season begins in October and extends through January, while pheasant season begins mid-November. The hunting area begins at a check-point and is separate from the year-round public wildlife viewing zone.

Description: Outside of hunting season, expanded public access begins in February. Catch the tail end of the migratory waterfowl season, and the bountiful shorebird display in the spring.
Description 2: These trails are open until hunting begins again in October.

Description: The demonstration wetlands at the headquarters are as start of field trips to the wildlife area and other local destinations like grasslands.
Description 2: More details here- show demo wetland

Description: The Yolo Basin Foundation's outdoor ecucation program, Discover the Flyway, hosted 60,000 students in its first decade (1997-2017).
Description 2: More details here

Description: Bats under the flyway
Vernal pool wildflower tours at Glide Tule Ranch and Grasslands Regional Park

The Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area hosts a diverse range of bird species that vary from season to season: ducks and geese that migrate long distances to the bypass in the winter, spring shorebirds foraging in shallow wetlands, summer nesting waterfowl and year-round residents, blackbirds flocking among tule reeds, and birds of prey hunting overhead.
Description 2: This section describes some of the common birds seen at the Wildlife Area. For a full list, take a look at the bird observations on eBird.

Description: Spectacular numbers of wintering waterfowl come to the Wildlife Area starting in October.
Description 2: The most common duck visitors are the northern pintail and the northern shoveler, but also look for the American widgeon, green-winged teal, canvasback, common goldeneye, and bufflehead. Pintails arrive as early as august, but most birds start arriving in October, peaking in December. They head north again come March and April.
Media Credit: add video of winter waterfowl + consider adding links e.g. https://www.allaboutbirds.org/guide/norsho
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: Wintering geese and swans tend to arrive in November, with over 10,000 snow geese and greater white-fronted geese visiting each season.
Description 2: Ross's geese, and tundra swans also visit. Geese arrive from as far north as Banks Island in the Arctic Archipelago and Wrangel Island off the north coast of Russia.
Media Credit: Flooded rice fields serve as important winter habitat for Pacific Flyway migratory birds such as Snow Geese. Aerial footage filmed and edited by Eric Holmes of the UC Davis Center for Watershed Sciences.
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: Other waterfowl stay closer to home.
Description 2: Birds like the coot, mallard, gadwall, and cinnamon teal --along with some shovelers-- nest at the Wildlife Area during the summer. Look for broods of ducklings on the permanent ponds in May through July.
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: Great blue herons, great egrets, snowy egrets, American bitterns and white pelicans, can also be found in the Wildlife Area year-round.
Waders like the white-faced ibis nest in the tule marsh over the summer and forage in the rice fields in the fall.
Many shorebirds (including avocets, black-necked stilts, killdeer, and coots) nest in the wildlife area in April.
Description 2: Chicks appear in May.

Description: Other shorebirds (including black-bellied plovers, greater yellowlegs, and long-billed dowitchers) head north in April to nest, returning to the wildlife area mid-summer.

Still others (phalaropes, willets, godwits, and some sandpipers) use the Wildlife Area as a stop on their migration to their northern summer breeding grounds, visiting in both the spring and late fall.
Look among the tangle of tule and cattails for red-winged blackbird, marsh wren, and rails like the Virginia rail and sora.
The grassland ecosystems host western meadowlark, yellow-billed magpie, and tree swallows.
Birds of prey include the red-tailed hawk, swainson's hawk, and northern harrier.
Description 2: Swainson's hawks arrive from the South in April to nest, staying through September, while other raptors can be spotted year-round.

Description: ...and check the trees for great horned owls!
(introcution - continuing to work together with partners to manage the area)
